document.docAuthor: Srinivasan, Umesh & Raza, Rashid Hasnain & Quader, Suhel
document.docTitle: Patterns of species participation across multiple mixed-species flock types in a tropical forest in northeastern India

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Patterns of species participation across multiple mixed-species flock types in a tropical forest in northeastern India

paragraph.docTitle:
Patterns of species participation across multiple mixed-species flock
types in a tropical forest in northeastern India

subSection.paragraph:
Umesh Srinivasana
,b,c*,
Rashid Hasnain Razac
,d and
Suhel Quaderc
,e

aPost-graduate
Programme in Wildlife Biology and Conservation, Wildlife Conservation

We studied mixed-species bird flocks in northeastern India to (a) develop a framework for quantifying species participation in mixed-species flocks, (b) characterize the ecology and behaviour of participant species, and (c) explore mechanisms influencing the coexistence of different mixed-species flock types . To characterize participation in mixed-species flocks, we implement a new method incorporating species abundances, minimizing potential biases in measuring participation arising from differences in the availability of flocking species. There are at least three distinct flock types in the lowland forests of northeastern India ; these flock types differ in the body mass and vertical stratum use of participant species. The “core” of mixed-species flocks was composed of a species group that differed much more in their foraging method in comparison with “attendant” species. The exchange of benefits and minimization of interspecific competition might lead to, and maintain, heterogeneity in foraging methods among core species of mixed-species flocks
.
Keywords: core species; feeding guild; insectivore; mixed-species flock; attendant species

First, variation in the propensity of different species to participate in mixed flocks and the mechanisms that might structure flocks and determine their composition remain to be satisfactorily explained. This might be partly because the quantification of flocking propensity is often simplistic, and based on metrics that do not incorporate the abundance (or “availability”) of different species, which might be expected to influence participation in flocks. Further, where multiple mixed-species flock types coexist, the mechanisms underlying the formation and stability of these discrete flock types has received little attention.

This study was carried out to (a) develop a rigorous framework for quantifying species participation in mixed-species flocks by taking into account species abundances, (b) characterize the composition of mixed-species bird flocks in terms of the ecology and behaviour of participant species, and (c) identify the potential mechanisms influencing participation in, and coexistence of different mixed-species flock types .

By comparing observed participation in mixed-species flocks with expected participation based purely on the overall abundances of participant species, we characterize species as participating more than expected, as expected, or less than expected in mixed flocks. This approach takes into account the availability of species to join flocks, and is among the first attempts to do so in characterizing species participation ( Srinivasan et al. 2010 ). Farley et al. (2008) also use abundance data to characterize flocking propensity. However, their approach measures the probability of a species being “left behind” by a moving flock, rather than comparing expected participation (based on abundance) with empirically observed participation. We also explore how the degree of participation by different species is related to aspects of the ecology of species, specifically with factors such as body mass, diet and foraging method.
Methods
Study area

Fieldwork was carried out in the Namdapha National Park (27 ◦ 23 ′ 30 ′′ to
27 ◦ 39 ′ 40 ′′ N
and 96 ◦ 15 ′ 2 ′′ to
96 ◦ 58 ′ 33 ′′ E
) in Changlang district , eastern Arunachal Pradesh , India , from early
December 2007
to mid-March 2008. Namdapha is situated in the Eastern Himalaya , a global Biodiversity Hotspot , and an Important Bird Area with about 500 bird species ( Islam and Rahmani 2004 ). Annual rainfall varies from 1500 to 3500 mm , most of which falls during the southwest monsoon months of April to October ( Datta 2007 ). Sampling was conducted in the Hornbill and Musathi areas in the buffer zone of the national park, at altitudes ranging from
500 to 650 m above sea level
. The habitat in this area is composed of dipterocarp-dominated lowland tropical evergreen forest ( Datta 2007 )
.
Sampling methods
Sampling for bird species abundance

Accurate measures of the abundance of difference bird species are essential for our method of assessing flocking propensity (see Analytical methods, below). To measure abundances, 23 line transects were established, ranging in length from 180 to 500 m , and oriented along random bearings. The minimum distance between adjacent transects was 500 m , to maximize independence between transects. Each transect was walked on four occasions, and in the case of four transects, on five occasions, thereby totalling 92 walks of 23 transects. For every species detected, the cluster size, bearing to the cluster (using a compass), and the detection distance to the centre of the cluster (using a laser rangefinder – 1000 Yardage Pro, Bushnell Corporation, Overland Park, KA, USA ) was recorded. A cluster was defined as a group of individuals of the same species, consisting of one or more individuals. For clusters with a detection distance below 15 m , detection distance was estimated visually to the nearest metre. Transects were walked between 08.30 and 12.30 hr.
Mixed-species flock sampling
Analytical methods
Abundance estimation
Mixed-species flock types

It was apparent during sampling that there were multiple flock types differing in species composition. Cluster analysis (using Jaccard’s similarity index with UPGMA, or Unweighted Pair Group Method with Arithmetic mean linkage) was used to identify different flock types based on the species composition of these flocks.
Species participation in mixed-species flocks

For each flock type , a candidate pool of species potentially contributing to flock composition was identified. This pool included all species that had been observed in at least one flock of that flock type . Species in this pool were then used to generate simulated flocks. The number of species drawn for each simulated flock was equal to the observed mean number of species in that flock type . Simulated flocks were filled sequentially by drawing species without replacement from the candidate species pool with a probability proportional to their abundance. The measure of abundance used as the probability weight was the abundance of conspecific groups of each species rather than the number of individuals. This is because flock participants join mixed-species flocks as conspecific groups rather than as individuals. This simulation method yielded “null” flocks with a composition reflecting what would be expected in the absence of differences in the tendency of species to join mixed-species flocks (i.e. based on the availability of species alone). As many null flocks were simulated as the observed number of flocks for each flock type . In this set of null flocks, the number of flocks in which a particular species occurred was counted. This proportion gives an estimate of the expected flocking propensity of a species based on abundance alone. This process was repeated 10,000 times to obtain a species-specific distribution of expected occurrence in mixedspecies flocks. The non-parametric 95% confidence limits (0.025 and 0.975 quantiles) of these distributions were obtained, and species were categorised into three classes in the following manner:

a. Core species . Species for which the observed number of occurrences in mixed-species flocks exceeded the upper 95% confidence limit of their occurrences expected by abundance alone. Our definition of core species is qualitatively similar to previous definitions ( Moynihan 1962 ; Peron and Crochet 2009 ), which are also based on the degree of species participation.

b. Regular attendants . Species for which the observed number of flock occurrences fell within the 95% confidence intervals of the distribution of their expected occurrences. Although attendant species are usually defined functionally as species that are not “nuclear” (i.e. not involved in initiating or maintaining mixed-species flocks; e.g. Moynihan 1962 ), we apply this term here to describe species that do not form the “core” of a flock. McClure (1967) also used degree of participation to define “attendant species” and to further classify attendants into usual, regular and accidental attendants.
c. Irregular attendants . Species for which the lower 95% confidence limit of the distribution of their expected occurrences exceeded the observed number of occurrences in mixed-species flocks.

Our method, as opposed to previously used metrics of flocking propensity, takes into account the abundance (or availability) of species. The abundance of a species is likely to play a role in determining flock participation. For instance, a common species with relatively low tendency to flock might occur in roughly the same number of flocks as a rare species with high flocking propensity. Earlier metrics would classify both of these species as having the same flocking propensity, whereas these metrics actually measure the probability of a species being present in a flock, rather than propensity to flock per se . We suggest, therefore, that measures of flocking propensity are likely to be much more realistic when the abundance of participant species has been taken into account.

Some species occurred as irregular attendants in one flock type but were either core species or regular attendants in another flock type . For comparisons between flock types , these species were not considered members of the flock type in which they occurred as irregular attendants. This is because an irregular attendant might occur in flocks through chance alone whereas a core species or regular attendant is likely to be associated more closely with other species within a given flock type .
Species characteristics
Mixed-species flocks types , body mass and vertical stratification

Species compositions of 101 mixed-species flocks were recorded from observations made along line transects, and during opportunistic sampling. Cluster analysis using Jaccard’s index with UPGMA identified three major flock types ( Figure 1 ). A Multiresponse Permutation Procedure, which tests for a significant difference between two or more groups, indicated clear differences between groups (chance-corrected within-group agreement, A = 0.122, probability of obtaining smaller or equal δ < 0.0001).
Canopy flocks
Understorey flocks
Large−bodied flocks

caption.paragraph: Figure 1. Cluster dendrogram of mixed-species bird flocks showing three distinct flock types, namely understorey flocks, canopy flocks and flocks composed of large-bodied bird species. Each “tip” represents a mixed-species flock.

subSection.paragraph: The mixed-species flock types identified were:

a. Understorey and midstorey flocks of predominantly small-bodied bird species ( n = 60 flocks). Core species in these flocks (see Appendix 1 for these and other details) were
Alcippe nipalensis
( Nepal Fulvetta),
Alcippe castaneceps
(Rufous-winged Fulvetta),
Rhipidura albicollis
(White-throated Fantail),
Erpornis zantholeuca
(White-bellied Erpornis ),
Abroscopus albogularis
(Rufous-faced Warbler),
Phylloscopus reguloides
(Blyth’s Leaf-warbler),
Seicercus castaneceps
(Chestnut-crowned Warbler),
Culicicapa ceylonensis
(Grey-headed Canary Flycatcher) and
Dicrurus remifer
(Lesser Racket-tailed Drongo). These are henceforth referred to as understorey flocks.

b. Canopy and midstorey foraging flocks ( n = 26 flocks), henceforth referred to as canopy flocks (Appendix 2). Core species in these flocks were
Melanochlora sultanea (Sultan Tit)
,
Pericrocotus flammeus (Scarlet Minivet)
,
Heterophasia annectans
(Rufous-backed Sibia),
Coracina melaschistos
(Blackwinged Cuckoo-shrike),
Sitta castanea
(Chestnut-bellied Nuthatch),
Sitta formosa (Beautiful Nuthatch)
and
Dicrurus remifer
(Lesser Racket-tailed Drongo).

c. Understorey and midstorey foraging flocks of predominantly large-bodied species ( n = 11 flocks) composed of species such as
Garrulax spp.
(laughing thrushes),
Cissa chinensis (Green Magpie)
,
Harpactes erythrocephalus (Redheaded Trogon)
and
Alophoixus flaveolus
(White-throated Bulbul). These are henceforth referred to as large-bodied flocks. We did not analyse species and guild participation in these flocks because of the low sample size.

The two flock types that foraged in the understorey and midstorey differed in the body masses of their participant species ( Figure 2 ), whereas the body masses of canopy flock participants overlapped with those of each of the two understorey–midstorey flocks ( Figure 2 ).
Patterns of species participation
Flocking and non-flocking species

We recorded 53 species that participated to varying degrees in either understorey or canopy mixed-species flocks. Thirty-four species did not participate in mixed-species flocks (henceforth, non-flocking species). As expected, most flocking species (83.0% of 53 species) were insectivores, compared with only 47.1% of 34 non-flocking species. Omnivores and nectarivores also occurred in mixed flocks, while carnivores, frugivores and granivores were never recorded. Both the nectarivores recorded in the study area were flock participants.
Diet guilds and foraging behaviour in core and attendant species

All core species in understorey and canopy flocks, as well as regular attendants in understorey flocks, were insectivorous. Although regular attendant species in canopy flocks were dominated by insectivores (18 species), omnivores (five species) and nectarivores (one species) also participated regularly in canopy mixed-species flocks.
Canopy Large−bodied Understorey flocks flocks flocks

caption.paragraph: Figure 2. Body mass distribution of participant species of three mixed-species flock types. “Large-bodied” flocks are composed of species that are significantly larger than species comprising “Understorey” flocks. Both these flocks are understorey–midstorey foraging flocks.

subSection.paragraph:
As hypothesized, core species in both flock types showed a relatively heterogeneous representation of different foraging method groups compared with regular attendant species. Only one hovering species,
Seicercus castaneceps
(Chestnut-crowned Warbler), occurred in canopy flocks (as a regular attendant). This species, however, was a core species in understorey flocks. Regular attendants in both flock types were dominated by foliage gleaners, followed by bark-surface feeders, salliers and hoverers ( Figure 3 ).
Mixed-species flocks types , body mass and vertical stratification

paragraph.materialsCitation: Although mixed-species flocks have been described in detail from tropical and temperate regions from South America , Europe, Africa and Asia, the co-existence of three sympatric but distinct flock types ( Figure 1 ) has been recorded before this study only in north-central Myanmar , also in dipterocarp forest ( King and Rappole 2001 ). In our study area, “understorey” and “large-bodied” mixed flocks both foraged in the understorey and lower midstorey, and species in “understorey” flocks were smaller than those in large-bodied flocks. Canopy flocks, which did not appear to

subSection.paragraph: Understorey Canopy Understorey Canopy flocks flocks flocks flocks

caption.paragraph: Figure 3. Foraging method groups in (A) core and (B) regular attendant species. Core species in both understorey and canopy mixed-species flocks showed a relatively heterogeneous representation of different foraging method groups compared with attendant species.

subSection.paragraph: Patterns of species participation
Diet as a predictor of species participation

Insectivorous species that we did not record participating in mixed-species flocks in the study area included species occupying bamboo or secondary forest, and some are known to occur in mixed-species flocks in those habitats ( Ali and Ripley 1983 ; Rasmussen and Anderton 2005 ). These were species such as
Xiphirhynchus superciliaris
(Slender-billed Scimitar-babbler) and
Macronous gularis
(Striped Tit-babbler). Other insectivorous species that did not participate in mixed-species flocks were flycatchers (genus
Niltava
and
Ficedula
) and wren-babblers (genus
Pnoepyga
and
Napothera
). Species of the genus
Niltava
are irregular participants in mixed-species flocks in other parts of Asia ( Chen and Hsieh 2002 ); species of the genus
Ficedula
are not known to flock. Flycatchers might not participate in mixed-species flocks because many are specific to certain microhabitats ( Ali and Ripley 1983 ), and might depend on food sources that are localized to these areas, rather than being randomly distributed in the environment. Similarly, it is possible that wren-babblers, owing to their microhabitat specificity (such as moss-covered rocks and logs and very dense undergrowth; Ali and Ripley 1983 ), also rely on specific types of prey that are localized in the habitat. A comparison of the diets of flycatchers and wren-babblers relative to other insectivores, together with a comparison of the spatial dispersion of these prey items, might lend support to, or refute the hypothesis that the distribution of prey influences flocking behaviour.

Omnivores and nectarivores that regularly participated in mixed-species flocks may join and follow flocks only part of the time to satisfy their dietary requirement of insects, accounting for their status as regular attendants, rather than as core species. Ominvorous and nectarivorous species might require higher levels of dietary protein during certain times of the year, for instance when provisioning nestlings. A testable prediction is that given constant insect abundances, these species will increase their participation in mixed-species flocks to benefit from foraging facilitation during these periods.
Foraging method guilds and core composition

King and Rappole (2001) observed “substantial species-specific variation in foraging behaviour” among flock participants. They concluded that foraging facilitation was not a major benefit accruing to flock members because species with a particular foraging method would be unable to facilitate the foraging of species with a different foraging method. However, it is the difference in foraging behaviour between participant species that is likely to offer foraging benefits. This might be through reduced competition, and the exchange of complementary benefits, either directly through mechanisms such as prey flushing, or indirectly through reducing the time spent on vigilance (allowing more time for foraging). Observations on the foraging success (measured in terms of foraging rate and time spent foraging) of core species in mixedspecies flocks would be required to tease out the nature and degree of benefit received by flock members. Species with different foraging methods would be expected to contribute and receive qualitatively and quantitatively different benefits. For instance, gleaners, poor at predator detection, might receive anti-predator benefits from associating with salliers (that play a sentinel role) and increase their foraging time in flocks. On the other hand, salliers might increase their foraging rate from gaining access to prey flushed by gleaners (see Sridhar et al. 2009 for a comprehensive review).

Our study examines some of the potential factors that might influence the composition of mixed-species flocks, and shows how diet, foraging method and body mass might be important in determining non-random patterns of species association. However, the influence of diet and foraging methods must be examined more rigorously. A finer classification of participant species in terms of diet and mode of feeding is desirable, as this will enable the examination of flocking propensity on a continuum, rather than based on categorical classifications scrounged from secondary literature. We identify questions that pertain to the mechanisms underlying species associations in mixed-species flocks, and advance testable hypotheses relating to the benefits of mixed-species flocking.

We thank the Wildlife Conservation Society – India Programme for financial support and the National Centre for Biological Sciences and Centre for Wildlife Studies for administrative support. We thank Pantha, Aphu and Khichaye Yobin for their enthusiasm in the field. We are grateful to the Arunachal Pradesh Forest Department for providing permission to carry out this research.
